image.altText: A man stands on a balcony with a frown on his face.

items.synopsis: Insurance companies have responded to back-to-back floods and soaring building costs by hiking premiums by around 30 per cent in just one year. But for the riskiest homes, cover is either refused outright, or offered at prices few can afford.

title.children: 'Who can afford that?' Scott was quoted nearly $32K for home and contents insurance as premiums soar

image.altText: The Woolnorth wind farm visible from Robbins Island and an inset of an orange-bellied parrot.

items.synopsis: A company wanting to build a wind farm in the migratory path of the critically endangered orange-bellied parrot says climate change poses a greater risk to the species than birds colliding with its turbines.

title.children: Only 77 of these parrots are left in the wild. A wind farm developer says a few deaths is a risk worth taking

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: After months of negotiations, the government’s signature housing promise is set to pass the Senate. So how many new homes will be built, how soon, and where across the country?

title.children: Where will these new homes be built? Here's what the government's new housing bill means for you

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: Two tourism companies on trial over the deadly Whakaari White Island volcano eruption have had charges dismissed.

title.children: More White Island tourism companies have charges dismissed, just one defendant remains

image.altText: A pregnant woman in a white dress with a horse on a beach.

items.synopsis: Emma Goyne believes she picked up the parasitic infection while cleaning her horse stable, which a neighbouring cat had been using as a litter box. Now she's pushing for tougher cat laws.

title.children: 'Cat poo on my hands': Emma fell sick when pregnant. She wants cat laws tightened

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un waves from a private train.

items.synopsis: Kim Jong Un's trip to Russia by rail has drawn attention to the traditional method of travel for North Korean leaders — luxury, armoured trains that have long been a part of the dynasty's lore.

title.children: Kim Jong Un has arrived in Russia by rail. Here's a look at his luxury armoured train

image.altText: A woman with a ponytail and dark long sleeve top standing in front of a tree

items.synopsis: An expert says there's been a spike in pneumonia infections in people with healthy immune systems. Circus performer Caitlyn Larsson, who had the infection for three months this year, is one of them.

title.children: Why are even healthy people getting sick with pneumonia this year?

image.altText: Angus Brayshaw is lying on a stretcher with a neck brace on and his eyes closed

items.synopsis: As Collingwood defender Brayden Maynard prepares to face the tribunal for his hit on Melbourne's Angus Brayshaw, the rest of the league awaits a verdict which some believe could shape the future of the game.

title.children: 'The whole footy world will be watching': Maynard verdict predicted to shape the future of footy

image.altText: An aerial view shows the charred remains of a building, with sparse trees nearby

items.synopsis: With a seemingly endless supply of guns, money and young men willing to act as mercenaries, tribal fighting in PNG has become akin to guerilla warfare.

title.children: Violence is so bad in this PNG community that police sealed it off to outsiders. The ABC got to go inside

image.altText: Soldiers attempt to tow a vehicle stuck in mud

items.synopsis: Harsh winter conditions will bring new challenges in the war in Ukraine. The fighting will not stop, but it will change its tempo — and both sides will face different tests, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Napoleon and Hitler battled the Marshall Mud. Could it be Putin's undoing?

image.altText: A man of Asian appearance wears glasses and stands speaking at a podium in a room, in front of a chalkboard and computer screens

items.synopsis: Banned from Australia over an alleged foreign interference plot in New South Wales, Chen Hong maintains he has done nothing wrong and continues to criticise the diplomatic stance taken by the former Coalition government.

title.children: Chinese scholar barred from Australia takes part in high-level dialogue between nations in Beijing

image.altText: Karen Andrews holds her hands up while sitting under a patio in her Queensland home

items.synopsis: Former Coalition cabinet minister Karen Andrews has revealed she endured harassment inside the House of Representatives, with a male colleague breathing heavily on the back of her neck.

title.children: 'That was a great question, thrusting and probing': The harassment Karen Andrews endured inside parliament

image.altText: A young man wearing a grey hoodie.

items.synopsis: A boy who repeatedly stabbed "typical, cheeky teenager" Declan Cutler during a deadly gang attack on a Melbourne street is jailed for 15 years.

title.children: Teens jailed over 'savage and totally unprovoked' fatal attack on Melbourne 16yo

image.altText: A man wearing a car backwards stands by a bright green car, with its doors open.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for the 32-year-old accused of stealing Nick Kyrgios's Tesla say police are taking too long to hand over the full brief of evidence and the case should be abandoned.

title.children: Canberra man accused of stealing Nick Kyrgios's Tesla wants case against him to be dropped

image.altText: Curtin Uni Wesley players stand arm in arm in a huddle during an Aussie rules match.

items.synopsis: Amateur female players call out derogatory and sexist online commentary after the Perth Football League A-grade grand final, saying "older men" are to blame for "disgusting" behaviour.

title.children: In shocking weather, an amateur women's footy team lost a low-scoring grand final — only to cop a sexist backlash

image.altText: Aaron Rodgers walks off the field with New York Jets trainers after injuring his ankle in their NFL season opener.

items.synopsis: Aaron Rodgers leaves the Jets' season opener with a suspected torn Achilles in the fourth minute after he arrived from Green Bay on a two-year deal worth $117 million.

title.children: The New York Jets paid more than $100 million for quarterback Aaron Rodgers. He lasted four plays

image.altText: Teammates congratulate a rugby league player after he scored a try

items.synopsis: One of them grew up in a Samoan village and didn't play a game of footy until he was 17. The other is a former reserve grade journeyman. Together, they're keeping the Roosters alive in 2023.

title.children: The unsung heroes keeping the Sydney Roosters improbable finals run alive

image.altText: junk food alongside healthy food

items.synopsis: The CSIRO report found construction workers had the poorest diets, while retirees and those in the fitness industry were the healthiest eaters.

title.children: Only 35pc of adults are eating enough veg, with alcohol and takeaway dominating diets, report finds

image.altText: A mother and father with a child in a wheelchair, and another child on a swing.

items.synopsis: Barely two months ago, Spencer Barton was an active and energetic five-year-old — but a shock diagnosis has turned the lives of him and his parents upside down, and left them battling not only his condition but the health system.

title.children: 5yo's 'truly heartbreaking' health battle leaves his family struggling to secure support

image.altText: A woman in a red hat leaning on a rusty bar of a gate.

items.synopsis: Australia's richest person Gina Rinehart has increased her stake in lithium firm Liontown Resources as global lithium giant Albemarle seeks to take it over. Meanwhile, the ASX has fallen. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Gina Rinehart ups stake in lithium miner Liontown Resources, ASX in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's not much movement today on the Australian share market as investors await the latest inflation figures from the US and this week's local unemployment data. The ASX 200 has edged higher after recovering its early losses as more sectors moved into the green. Fuel supplier Viva Energy (-6.8 per cent) slumped on reports that Swiss commodity trader Vitol could sell a stake in the firm. Vitol owns nearly half of Viva Energy. The big banks are suffering modest losses, while big miners are higher after an increase in iron ore prices. Rio Tinto is up 1.8 per cent. Healthcare stocks have also gained led by Telix Pharmaceuticals (+3.8 per cent). Financial services firm Link Administration (+5.2 per cent) is the best performer on the ASX 200
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market treads water

children.content: There's not much movement today on the Australian share market as investors await the latest inflation figures from the US and this week's local unemployment data.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The value of Australia's housing stock keeps increasing. The Bureau of Statistics says the total value of residential dwellings in Australia rose by $325 billion to $10.09 trillion over the June quarter. That's near the record high seen in March 2022, just before the Reserve Bank started raising interest rates from record lows in May 2022. The mean (middle) price of properties rose by $25,200 to $912,000 over the June quarter. The number of homes in Australia increased by 52,200 to 11.05 million. Housing in New South Wales is the most expensive, while the cheapest housing is in the Northern Territory. Mean prices: NSW: $1,167,500 ACT: $947,900 Victoria: $904,800 Queensland: $781,600 South Australia: $684,700 Western Australia: $671,000 Tasmania: $662,200 Northern Territory: $512,700. A shortage of properties and more migration keeps pushing up prices despite 12 interest rate rises since May last year. Here's more from my colleague Kate Ainsworth.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian homes worth $10.1 trillion

featuredLink.title: House prices rise for sixth straight month, with interest rate outlook likely to see 'active' selling season

children.content: The value of Australia's housing stock keeps increasing.
The Bureau of Statistics says the total value of residential dwellings in Australia rose by $325 billion to $10.09 trillion over the June quarter.
That's near the record high seen in March 2022, just before the Reserve Bank started raising interest rates from record lows in May 2022.

props.alt: A graph showing the value of Australian housing

children.content: The mean (middle) price of properties rose by $25,200 to $912,000 over the June quarter.
The number of homes in Australia increased by 52,200 to 11.05 million.
Housing in New South Wales is the most expensive, while the cheapest housing is in the Northern Territory.
A shortage of properties and more migration keeps pushing up prices despite 12 interest rate rises since May last year.
Here's more from my colleague Kate Ainsworth.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Online shopping took off during the pandemic, and now with the rising cost-of-living, more of us are being careful with how we spend our hard earned money — even on the essentials. Have you changed how you do your weekly (or fortnightly, or monthly!) shop for those household and grocery items that are traditionally more expensive — like dishwashing tablets, nappies, cleaning products, or that one specific product you just can't find in store? Are you jumping online to get the best possible deal on Amazon, Coles, Woolworths, or another online store? If that sounds like you, we want to hear from you! Business reporter Emily Stewart is exploring how our grocery shopping habits have changed for a story with ABC News — if you want to share your story, get in touch with her by emailing Stewart.Emily@abc.net.au .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📣 Are you doing more of your weekly shop online? We want to hear from you

image.altText: An illustration of a pink egg in a blue nest with flying money notes with dollar signs on them

items.synopsis: As  the influence of superannuation funds – economically and politically — continues to grow, transparency over how member money gets used becomes crucial, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: With super assets set to top $9 trillion in 2041, should funds be more accountable about how they spend members' money?

image.altText: A woman voting at night at a cardboard polling booth

items.synopsis: The governor-general has issued the writ for the Voice to Parliament referendum, setting in motion the time line for the nationwide vote.

title.children: Voice referendum key dates for postal and early votes have been confirmed. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A header approaches the camera whilst harvesting barley

items.synopsis: Australian farmers are set to cash in, as a new report shows the agricultural export trade to China to be be valued at $16.6 billion annually.

title.children: Farm exports to China have jumped to a record high despite damaging tariffs

image.altText: A close up of a grey, fluffy koala in a tree, looking right at the camera.

items.synopsis: The halt covers more than 8,400 hectares of forest, in pockets of 'koala hubs' within the national park proposed on the mid north coast.

title.children: Timber harvesting stopped in NSW forests within proposed Great Koala National Park

image.altText: Tom Curry is shown a yellow card

items.synopsis: Four games. Five similar incidents. Three different decisions. As rugby grapples with its head-contact rules, players and coaches plead for consistency, writes Simon Smale.

title.children: Five incidents, one red card, two yellows and three unpunished: Inconsistencies slammed at Rugby World Cup

image.altText: Jimmy sits in his living room on his laptop.

items.synopsis: When a pattern emerged of people with brain injuries being scammed, a team in Melbourne designed a program to fight back.

title.children: 'Thank you darling': How simple phrases of love turned Jimmy's life upside down

image.altText: Cars and rubble sit in a street in Derna, Libya.

items.synopsis: Deadly storm winds and heavy floods have hit Libya over the past two days, with estimates of the number of people killed ranging from hundreds to thousands.

title.children: Thousands feared dead as storm floods Libya

image.altText: A man sitting, looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Mustafa Chiahad's son was buried beneath the rubble of his parents' home in Talat N'Yaaqoub. The town, near the epicentre of Morocco's earthquake, has turned in to ground zero for destruction.

title.children: 'I don't have the words to describe it': Devastated families count cost of Morocco's quake

image.altText: A composite image of a fire ant and an arm that's been bitten

items.synopsis: Fire ants are considered a greater invasive pest than cane toads, rabbits, feral cats and foxes combined, with documents showing a queen was discovered in Melbourne this year.

title.children: Fire ant 'alarm' for Victoria as bite victim relives holiday disaster

items.synopsis: Police are investigating after a man in his 20s died while abseiling at Belmore Falls in Barrengarry.

title.children: Man dies after falling from a cliff while abseiling in Southern Highlands

image.altText: A group of rescuers in a cave lift a man on a stretcher using ropes

items.synopsis: Rescuers have pulled an American researcher out of a Turkish cave more than a week after he became seriously ill 1,000 metres below its entrance, said the Speleological Federation of Türkiye.

title.children: 'I kept throwing up blood': Researcher stuck in cave thought he was not going to live
